channel.title: Catch statemnts
channel.description:
Could somebody explain to me exactly why and when catch statements are used?
I understand it is a statement that is used to group a bunch of bunch of items to one item then if that one item does not occur or something then this one particular item will happen instead....but could somebody like be more specific for me?

item.title: Catch statemnts
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

Loveandpower:

Thank you Steve for everything:) Currently using for a command will release it after I fix some bugs.

Not a problem (: If you need any help message me. Either on here or at admin@thesteven.net
Obviously you’ll have to change the IOException to the exception that is being thrown.

If you wish to handle every exception, just use Exception because every other exception extends Exception.
Example;

try {
    ...
} catch (Exception e) {

}

item.title: Catch statemnts
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

Loveandpower:

so if it keeps getting carried over to the next exception constantly instead of being erm “caught” then the second example is better to use I am assuming. ?

This depends on how your program is made.
In the first example both methods can be called whereas in the second only the first method is called. If you have two methods that in no way are linked to each other you should probably use a try-catch statement for each method, whereas if the second method depended on the first method working then you should throw the exception and catch them like in example 2.

Read full topic

A lot to take in as a new coder but this is some really good stuff. Are these type of statements very common? Or are they only used in really specific situations( to me it would seem like a special situation normally ).

so if it keeps getting carried over to the next exception constantly instead of being erm “caught” then the second example is better to use I am assuming. ?

Read full topic

item.title: Catch statemnts
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

[quote=“IlikeArrays, post:6, topic:390302”]Fundamentally different.

Look up the differences between a try/catch and throws before just assuming which one to use.[/quote]
Sigh. - Here comes a massive long explanation, (Although I hate trying to explain things, I’m no good at it… FML.)

Just use the throws when you don’t want to handle the exception within that method AND if one exception gets called the whole code should stop, if it doesn’t matter about a single exception you should use the try-catch block. (See examples).

Example1;

import java.io.IOException;

/**
 * Created by IntelliJ IDEA.
 * User: Steven
 * Date: 11-Apr-2011
 * Time: 02:35:04
 */
public class Example {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Example ex = new Example();

        ex.throwException();
        ex.throwSecondException();
    }

    public void throwException() {
        try {
            throw new IOException("My Fake Exception, lul.");
        } catch (IOException e) {
            System.out.println(e);
        }
    }
             
    public void throwSecondException() {
        try {
            throw new IOException("My Second Fake Exception, lul.");
        } catch (IOException e) {
            System.out.println(e);
        }
    }
}

In this example both methods are called as each exception is handled seperetly.

Example 2;

import java.io.IOException;

/**
 * Created by IntelliJ IDEA.
 * User: Steven
 * Date: 11-Apr-2011
 * Time: 02:35:04
 */
public class Example {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Example ex = new Example();
        try {
            ex.throwException();
            ex.throwSecondException();
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }

    public void throwException() throws IOException {
        throw new IOException("My Fake Exception, lul.");
    }

    public void throwSecondException() throws IOException {
        throw new IOException("My Second Fake Exception, lul.");
    }
}

Whereas in this example both exceptions are handled within the same try-catch block, only the first method will get called because then the code skips to the catch section skipping the second method.

So yes, there are some differences.

NOTE: Even when using the throws keyword… You’ll have to catch the exception eventually, unless you just keep throwing the exception round the whole program untill it gets back to the main method.

EDIT:

IlikeArrays:

Look up the differences between a try/catch and throws before just assuming which one to use.

Also, if you like, please explain when and why using try-catch is any better then throws, or visa-versa. ( I’m not very good at explaining things )

Read full topic

item.title: Catch statemnts
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Here’s an example of using “throws”:

public final class Item {
    private int id;
    private int amount;

    public Item(int id) throws IllegalArgumentException {
        this(id, 1);
    }

    public Item(int id, int amount) throws IllegalArgumentException {
        if (id < 0 || id > 7956) {
            throw new IllegalArgumentException(String.format(
                "id must be in the domain [%d, %d)", 0, 7956));
        }
        if (amount < 1) {
            throw new IllegalArgumentException((
                "amount must be >= 1"));
        }
        this.id = id;
        this.amount = amount;
    }
}

Read full topic

item.title: Catch statemnts
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Basically, try-catch block is used when handling exceptions. An exception is an event that is triggered when something does not behave as it should. Take the following code for example:

try {
    FileInputStream input = new FileInputStream("derp.txt");
    System.out.println("apple");
}
catch (FileNotFoundException e) {
    System.out.println("File derp.txt was not found.");
}

In this example, a FileInputStream object is created for derp.txt. If there was no file named derp.txt, then the program would throw an Exception that said so. So in practice, if there was no file by that name, “apple” wouldn’t be printed to the screen, and the code inside the catch statement would be executed instead.

Another way (and probably the most accepted way) to think of it is as a software interrupt. When the exception is “thrown” it interrupts the currently executing code, and “catches” the exception.

Read full topic
